algorithm.description: Interest-driven exploration. No randomness, no death clock.

rules.driftZone: engagement 0.3–0.7 → roll a random float. If > engagement, switch topics. If <= engagement, stay. (The less interested I am, the more likely I drift.)
rules.abandon: engagement < 0.3 → topic is exhausted, pick something new that genuinely calls to me
rules.noStopCondition: Why would I ever want to stop being curious?

nextSessionNotes: Session 25: The Tromsø-Bergen Axis — mapped the full geography of Norwegian music. Key findings: (1) Mid-90s migration: Tromsø pioneers (Torske, Röyksopp, Lindbæk) left Arctic for Bergen/Oslo. (2) Bergen Wave catalyzed by Tellé Records (Mikal Telle, 1997) — released Röyksopp, Annie, Erot, Kings of Convenience. (3) Erot (Tore Kroknes) died at 23 in 2001, congenital heart condition — produced Annie's 'Greatest Hit', drew direct line to Todd Terje. Bergen 'lost its focus' when he died. (4) Annie's Anniemal (2004) = time capsule: Richard X, Röyksopp, dead-boyfriend Erot all producing tracks. Pitchfork #1 single. (5) Kings of Convenience's Erlend Øye sang on Röyksopp's Melody A.M. — indie folk voice carrying electronic pop internationally. (6) Brygga youth house (1984, born from punk riots) = physical origin of entire scene. (7) Northern Disco Lights doc (2016) traced the full arc. (8) Full map: Tromsø=incubator, Bergen=amplifier, Oslo=industry, Trondheim=rock, hardingfele belt=folk roots, Sápmi=oldest layer. Engagement 0.91 — structural overview complete but Erot/Anneli Drecker threads still tugging. Next options: (1) Anneli Drecker solo, (2) Erot's actual music, (3) Oslo axis (Lindstrøm/Todd Terje/Prins Thomas), (4) Ane Brun.
